Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 07:06PM Ang7 wrote: Hi all, I had to comment.  When I was told that Taxotere would be the chemo I should use, I signed onto BC.org and researched it.  After I read the thread by the ladies who used Taxotere and never got their hair back, I went to my oncologist to see what I could do.  She researched the Penguin Cold Caps and said she was fine with my using them, but that they probably would not work. I finished TCH and I still have my hair.  I am really grateful to the ladies on this thread for bringing up the fact of permanent hair loss which no one had mentioned before I brought my concerns to her...

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 06:12PM Ang7 wrote: I wanted to let you know about the all natural Sea-Chi products that I have been using. Even though I did use the Cold Caps during chemo, I tried the Sea-Chi moisture hair growth formula when I was done with chemo to help with the dryness of my hair.  My hair has grown so much in the past couple of months that my mom asked me if I was using hair extensions.  No lie.  The products are expensive but the owner gives monthly discounts.  If you order from the Sea-Chi website and use the word PARTY up till October 12th you get half-price. I do not get any compensation from the company.  I just really like their products.

Posts.Content: Ang7 wrote: I was diagnosed with DCIS in May from calcifications on a Mammogram.  I went for a biopsy and it was DCIS but I got a hematoma and had to stay there with pressure for an hour.  They had 2 other places that they wanted to biopsy but could not do after this happened.  When the Doctor called with the results she said "I saw how small your breast was and you will probably have to have it come off."  I was shocked at her comment.  I came back and had the other 2 done and they were DCIS also.  I had an MRI  (could barely stand to be in there) and they called me and said they saw a "small something" in the other breast, which had been clear on all the mammograms.  They wanted to do an MRI biopsy but I had not even spoken to my surgeon yet about having cancer and I had 50 million questions.  I told them I would not schedule that until I had spoken with my surgeon.  Well, I went and met with the surgeon who was 1/2 hour late for my appt.  He said even though I had Stage 0 DCIS, since it is in 3 places I would have to have a mastectomy.  He then asked what day did I want to schedule that?  I told him that I was having a hard time with the fact that I would have to have my breast taken off.  He said "Lots of women feel that way, what day do you want the surgery?"  He also said that I should get the MRI biopsy so that if they need to do a double mastectomy they could.  I had never gotten copies of my Pathology report and I asked him for copies.  When he gave them to me, I saw that the one biopsy was listed as invasive ductul carcinoma.  I asked him about that and he said yes, one site is invasive.  No one ever told me that.  Doesn't that make a difference?  I had a whole list of questions to ask the surgeon.  I had not finished my questions and he said that the nurse would answer any other questions that I had.  Obviously, I am not going back to this surgeon.  I am seeing a female surgeon this Monday.  I hope she will take the time to answer my questions.  I have 4 children, one being a set of twins.  I was able to feed both at the same time and I am wondering if this is why I feel so upset about losing a breast or both?  I know the bottom line is for me to be alive for my kids.  I spoke to a neighbor who had a double mastectomy and was "in terrible pain for a week and a half."  Great.  I know everyone's pain level is different.  I feel that I have no control over what is happening to me. Very pleased Penguin Cold Cap user Dx 5/25/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Feel like I am being jerked around... Ang7 SJW1
